parts:
You basically have an interest-driven brain running on “research mode” by default. The trick is not to fight that, but to design your work so that:

- boring but necessary tasks are sliced thin and scaffolded  
- long-running projects have visible progress and novelty  
- your tendency to chase interesting things is harnessed, not suppressed  

I’ll break this into concrete systems you can actually run.

---

## 1. Reframe: your brain is not “lazy”, it is interest-prioritised

Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is, in practice, less about “low discipline” and more about:

- **Interest over importance**: your brain allocates attention to “interesting now”, not “important later”.
- **Low tolerance for friction**: if a task is vague, boring, or has a high activation cost, you will automatically defer it.
- **Hyperfocus**: when something *is* interesting and well-scoped, you can work longer and deeper than most people.

So the game is:

> Reduce friction + increase interest + make progress visible.

Everything below is aimed at those three levers.

---

## 2. Kill procrastination at the “activation energy” stage

Most procrastination happens *before* you start, not after. So focus on making “starting” stupidly easy.

### 2.1. Always define the next **atomic** action

If an item on your list is “work on website”, your brain is right to ignore it — it is not a task, it is a cloud.

Instead, tasks must be expressed so that you can start them in under 60 seconds.

Examples:

- Bad: “Write section on Goodhart’s Law.”  
  Better: “Open `goodhart.tex` and draft 3 bullet points for subsection 2.1.”

- Bad: “Fix SEO on site.”  
  Better: “Open homepage HTML and add `<title>` and `<meta description>` based on X.”

Make this a hard rule:  
> No project is allowed to sit in your system without at least one well-defined **next action**.

You will find that once you start, you often continue. The job of the system is to get you to “start” repeatedly.

### 2.2. The five-minute rule (properly)

The “Five-Minute Rule” is:  
> Commit not to *finish* a thing, only to do **five minutes**.

Used correctly, you *lower* the emotional barrier:

- “I must complete this section” → heavy, aversive  
- “I only have to poke at this for 5 minutes” → low threat

Set a timer for 5 minutes and *explicitly* allow yourself to stop once it rings. You usually will not, but knowing you can walk away keeps the panic down.

### 2.3. Make starting a reflex via “if–then” plans

These are implementation intentions:

- “If it is 9:30 and I sit at my desk, **then** I open [project file] and do five minutes on the next atomic task.”
- “If I finish a lesson, **then** I spend 10 minutes on [long-run project].”

You are using a fixed cue (time, place, previous action) to automate the otherwise heavy “decide what to do” step, which is where ADHD often stalls.

---

## 3. Build a project system that respects an ADHD brain

You are dealing with projects spanning weeks or months. You need a structure that keeps them:

- visible  
- broken into small chunks  
- rewarding on short time scales  

Think of this like designing a workflow for a slightly distractible but brilliant PhD student you manage.

### 3.1. One “Project Ledger” as single source of truth

Have *one* place where you track long-run projects (not ten apps):

For each project:

- Name  
- One-sentence purpose: “Why does this exist?”  
- Current phase (e.g. “Exploration / Drafting / Implementation / Polish”)  
- This week’s one to three concrete goals  
- Next three atomic actions

This can be a simple markdown table, Kanban board, or plain list. The key is: your brain should not need to remember anything. Externalise all of it.

### 3.2. Weekly “heartbeat” review (30–45 minutes)

Once per week, you do a **heartbeat**:

- Look at each active long-run project.
- Ask:
  - Did I move this forward this week?  
  - What is the next visible milestone (that fits in ~1 week)?  
  - What are the next 1–3 atomic actions?

Update the ledger and schedule **just the next few moves**, not the whole chess game.

This solves the “I lost the plot of this project, better open Twitter” problem.

### 3.3. Work in short “sprints” with a clear “definition of done”

Borrow lightly from software:

- Choose 1–2 key projects per week.
- For each, define a **1-week sprint goal** with a precise “definition of done”.

Examples:

- “By Sunday: have a 1-page outline + list of lemmas for the Goodhart paper. Done = outline written in `outline.md` and at least 5 candidate lemmas listed.”
- “By Sunday: refactor homepage CSS to use a single colour palette. Done = CSS file updated, screenshots stored, old file backed up.”

Your ADHD brain likes finishing things. You are giving it small finish lines instead of one gigantic, distant one.

### 3.4. Limit work-in-progress (WIP)

Work-In-Progress (WIP) is everything you are trying to actively push forward at once.

ADHD + too many parallel projects = constant context switching and no visible completion.

As a rule:

- Max 2 “heavy” cognitive projects at a time.
- Others are parked in a “Later / Incubator” list.

You *can* capture ideas for them, but you do not let them demand real work until one of the active ones is done or reaches a natural pause.

---

## 4. Make long-running work *interesting* to you

You explicitly said: perseverance is heavily interest-dependent. So design in interest.

### 4.1. Give each project an “intellectual hook”

For every project, write down a question that actually tickles your brain, not just the instrumental goal.

Examples:

- Tuition website: “What is the most elegant way to structure explanations so that a borderline-passing student can ‘click’ into real understanding with minimal redundancy?”
- Goodhart’s Law research: “Can I derive a sharp, toy model theorem that actually captures the trade-off between benchmark optimisation and real-world performance?”

Put that hook at the top of the project note. Re-read it at the start of each work block. You’re reminding your brain: *this is not busywork, this is an intellectual problem*.

### 4.2. Prime yourself with micro-research

Before a work block on a long project:

- Spend 5–10 minutes reading something slightly above your current implementation level (a paper, chapter, blog post).
- Jot 1–2 ideas on how it connects to your project.

This satisfies the curiosity drive and makes the ensuing grind feel like “applying something interesting” instead of “mindless labour”.

### 4.3. Alternate “fun” and “mechanical” tasks

Within a 60–90 minute block:

- Start with 10–20 minutes of a cognitively rich task (deriving a lemma, designing an argument, refactoring architecture).
- Follow with 20–30 minutes of more mechanical implementation (typing up, cleaning code, formatting, LaTeX, etc.).
- Repeat.

This lets you “pay” for the boring bits with the interest gained from the fun bits.

---

## 5. Time strategy: power blocks, not full rigid schedules

Full calendar time-blocking can fail hard for ADHD; one disruption and the whole scaffolding collapses.

A compromise:

### 5.1. Daily “power blocks” for deep work

Define **2 power blocks** per day (they can be 45–90 minutes depending on your energy), e.g.:

- 10:00–11:15  
- 16:00–17:00  

Rules:

- Power blocks are for long-run projects only, no admin.  
- You choose in advance which project each block is for.  
- During the block, your only options are:
  1. Work on the chosen project’s next atomic task, or  
  2. Stare at the wall / sit there  

No third option (no email, no phone, no “just checking news”). Your brain quickly learns that working is less painful than boredom.

The rest of the day can be flexible: tutoring, errands, reading, small tasks.

### 5.2. “Menu” of tasks instead of fixed micro-scheduling

For each power block, have a menu of 3–5 atomic tasks for that project. When the block starts, pick whichever feels least aversive.

You keep commitment to **the block and the project**, but allow choice about *which* micro-task. This leverages your need for autonomy without losing direction.

---

## 6. Make it more enjoyable: gamification that is not childish

You likely do not care about cutesy apps. But you might care about:

- **Streaks**: number of days in a row you touched a key project (even 10 minutes counts).
- **Points**: assign points to tasks based on difficulty; track weekly totals; try to beat last week.
- **Progress graphs**: pages written, lemmas proved, lines of code committed, site visits as you ship changes.

The key is: **visible evidence** that the project is moving. ADHD brains are very responsive to immediate feedback; graphs and streaks make the long-term visible.

---

## 7. Guardrails against distraction (the boring but necessary part)

### 7.1. Environmental design

- Physical: keep your main work zone as “single-purpose” as possible (desk = work, couch = browsing/reading).
- Digital:
  - Close all unrelated tabs before a power block.
  - Use full-screen mode on editor or PDF.
  - Consider website blockers during power blocks (for example, apps that block social media / news sites for set periods).

You are designing a **default** where doing the project is easier than escaping it.

### 7.2. Separate “capture” from “follow”

When you get a great idea mid-task (“Oh, I should read that paper / refactor that other project / Google this tangential thing”):

- Dump it in a quick capture list (notepad, text file, whatever).
- Do not follow it now; review the capture list at the end of the day or during weekly heartbeat.

This respects your creativity without allowing it to hijack your current block.

---

## 8. Emotional layer: reduce guilt, increase curiosity

ADHD often comes with years of internalised “I should be better at this” frustration. That frustration itself becomes a procrastination trigger.

A few useful mindsets:

- Replace “I must finish this” with “I am curious what happens if I push this forward for 30 minutes.”
- Treat yourself as a system designer, not a moralising judge.  
  “This setup produced distraction; how do I modify the setup?” rather than “Why am I like this?”

You will still have “off” days; the point of the system is not perfection, but resilience: even on a low-energy day, you can still knock out one 10–15-minute atomic task and keep the project alive.

---

## 9. When to bring in professional or pharmacological support

Since you describe your Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder as mild and non-disruptive to work, lifestyle and systems may already take you far. But it is still worth saying:

- If long-term, important projects keep stalling *despite* good systems…
- Or if stress, anxiety, or sleep begin to suffer because of unfinished work…

…then it is reasonable to speak with a clinician who understands adult ADHD. They may suggest adjustments ranging from Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) to medication. That is not a failure of willpower; it is just using another tool.

---

If you like, I can help you turn one specific ongoing project into a concrete “ledger + sprint + power block” plan, with actual atomic tasks written out so you can test-drive this framework in the real world.
